book.name: Guide to ELA Classroom Activities that Promote Life Skills, College, and Career Readiness

chapter.title: ELA guide a rich compilation of materials for adult education practitioners
chapter.content:
The Guide to ELA Classroom Activities that Promote Life Skills, College and Career Readiness (ELA Guide) was also developed by a group of adult basic education and ESOL teachers and professional development specialists in Massachusetts. The working group drew on research from a variety of sources, including a study conducted by ATLAS, which informed their development of TIF. They also sought input from transition to college and workforce development stakeholders. The result is a rich compilation of materials for adult education practitioners in forms that can be immediately applied in classrooms.

This topic introduces the ELA Guide and describes the key features.

chapter.title: Seven essential competencies align with workforce preparation activities
chapter.content:
Section IV of the ELA Guide identifies seven essential competencies and associated evidence-based indicators students need to succeed in college, workplace, and civic life. Like the TIF skill categories, these seven competencies align very well with workforce preparation skills. The ELA Guide provides two tiers, or levels, of sample tasks for each of the seven competencies.

Essential Competencies

Competency

Evidence-based Indicators

I. Collect, organize, and interpret information

Comprehend/evaluate texts at level, take notes, summarize, report out

II. Share information and ideas with others

Communicate, collaborate, present, use graphics and handouts

III. Solve problems

Identify, name, and solve challenging problems

IV. Argue for points and negotiate among positions

Present logical arguments, cite evidence/reasons, respect different views

V. Conduct activities in a professional manner

Demonstrate civility and competence, be punctual, meet deadlines

VI. Plan and follow through on tasks

Develop goals, determine realistic action steps, persist

VII. Demonstrate self-efficacy, self-advocacy, and self-direction

Take responsibility for self, take initiative, secure assistance or support

chapter.title: Key features of the ELA guide
chapter.content:
Some of the key features of the ELA Guide are:

  • Instructional tasks that students might perform to demonstrate the attainment of each competency. The instructional tasks can serve as targets for classroom instruction and activities.
  • Instructional tasks for each competency that are sorted into two tiers, each associated with a specific range of National Reporting System Educational Functioning and College and Career Readiness Standards levels.
  • Examples of competency-related tasks that are transferred across three contexts: life skills, college-based, and career-based.
  • Competencies and sample instructional tasks that tie to the College and Career Readiness Standards for ELA reflecting how instruction can prepare students for life and the workplace, as well as for academic advancement.
  • A Baseline Skills Index to track the sub-skills that are required for students to perform the instructional tasks successfully at any level.
